title: Atheist Debunks Apologist (in a debate) | Part 7 of 8
description:
This is a formal debate between myself and Cameron Bertuzzi on whether horrendous suffering disproves God. This is my closing statement.

1. I heard this disturbing example when Joe Schmid cited Sharon Street in this video around the 6hr(!) 50min mark
2. See Rebuttal 1‚Ä¶
3. I was already aware of the Craig post, which is why when I quoted him in my first rebuttal, it was from a 2019 publication. Either he‚Äôs changed his mind, thinks these features generally speaking constitute a good argument, doesn‚Äôt review popular level books published in his name by other people, or is dishonest (I don‚Äôt think this last option is the correct choice btw). 
4. Maybe those who experience horrific suffering and feel like they‚Äôre growing closer to God because of it are in tune with reality, and those who don‚Äôt experience it in this life will in an afterlife. Alternatively, maybe those who are destroyed by horrific suffering are the ones who truly look reality in the face and buckle, and the ones that don‚Äôt are just making the best of a bad situation based on predictable human psychological features produced by evolution. Either way, the empirical data of people‚Äôs testimony doesn‚Äôt seem to be the best way to adjudicate between these two options when considering the kind of argument we‚Äôre discussing here. 
5. See Erik Wielenberg, A morally unsurpassable God must create the best
6. Taking some inspiration from what Wielenberg said in my interview with him around the 31 min mark. He seems to also endorse the moral principle I have suggested.

Enns writes: ‚ÄúBiblical Archaeologists are about as certain as you can be‚Ä¶that the conquest of Canaan as the Bible describes it did not happen.‚Äù See also Book of Exodus, Session 5: The Crossing of the Sea Exodus 14‚Äì15, Yale University, p. 8. From the session: ‚ÄúVery little can be said about the exodus as history‚Äù, and the story is ‚Äúfull of legendary details and lacks supporting evidence from archaeology or from nonbiblical sources‚Äù
https://divinity.yale.edu/sites/default/files/exodus-5-the-crossing-of-the-sea_0.pdf

2. Luke Timothy Johnson (2010), The New Testament: A Very Short Introduction, Oxford University Press, p. 8 (Kindle). Johnson writes: ‚ÄúThe four gospels are notoriously difficult to use as sources for reconstructing the historical Jesus. Their faith perspective, their literary interdependence, and the major and minor disagreements among them make a satisfying account of the events of Jesus‚Äô life impossible‚Ä¶the Gospels are severely limited as historical sources‚Äù
Ibid, p. 63. Johnson also writes: ‚ÄúPaul is, remarkably, both the earliest self-designated Pharisee and the only first-hand witness to Jesus‚Äô resurrection (1 Cor 9:1).‚Äù
